value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">meditations in real people, acting a story. And so</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the vast accumulations that have littered from books</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">down into the great [college?] room <del>flow</del> meander</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">over the page. He cannot write a sentence without</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">remembering what some other man has said. <del>But</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>instead of</del> <del>His vision is multiple. He sees</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with the eyes of a thousand men; yet <del>about</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He uses the eyes of a thousand dead men to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">verify what he sees. <del>Yet</del> He <del>does not</del> Yet all</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">these reflections serve to enrich his own vision.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Man is <del>melancholy, now</del> <del>But he has been</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Man has been melancholy always; in Greece in Rome;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he has been read always; he has been cruel; he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">has tortured & killed; & even in England</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>yet there</del> is a tolerance in his soliloquy: he is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He sees through a thousand <quote source="#" rend="inline">green shades</quote> what lies</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">immediately before him – the unhappy heart of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">man. Yet these innumerable instances of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">passion, of melancholy, the reflections serve to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">chequer the immediate spectacle. There is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>a</del> From books he has won <del>the</del> tolerance,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">mediations, the sense that we are not single</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">figures, but <del>so</del> innumerably repeated; <del>the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>individual comes</del> <del>He</del> In pursuit of melancholy he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">travels over the whole world, though he has never</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">left his college room. [pirtances?] are drawn</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from all [guardu?]. <del>They</del> are illustrated by</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">anecdotes. <del>And then</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>For th</del> Yet though the theme is Melancholy, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">treatment is humorous. <del>Over the</del> We are at a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">remove from the thing treated. We are evading it</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">generally. We are engaging the spectacle of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">melancholy, not sharing in its anguish.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">That is the <del>present</del> gift of the book –</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There we develop the other <del>gif</del> faculties that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the play left dormant: to [sense?], to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>speculate, to</del> the private faculties: the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the      to gloss, to [treat?], to compare, to feel our</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">eyes upon the writer, & to find at the</l>
